ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: HyperNEAT Tutorial?
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ken, Thanks. I still think that a (possibly moderated) wiki may be useful so that others can share their experiences/knowledge, but a very good start

Hi Ken,

Thanks. I still think that a (possibly moderated) wiki may be usef=
ul  
so that others can share their experiences/knowledge, but a very good =
 
start indeed.

Meanwhile, I've drawn up a rudimentary glossary of HyperNE=
AT terms to  
help clarification of discussions here in our lab. Maybe it's=
  
something you'd want to add, so I thought I'd share it.

HyperNEAT Gloss=
ary
	=95 Substrate configuration: a set of nodes arranged in space (2D, 3D,=
  
grid, circular, sandwich, etc)
	=95 Connectivity pattern: a set of direc=
ted weighted links between  
(some of) the nodes in a substrate configurati=
on
	=95 Substrate: a substrate configuration and a connectivity pattern,  
=
i.e. a directed graph with weights over the edges
	=95 CPPN: Compositional =
Pattern Producing Network
	=95 Connective CPPN: a CPPN interpreted to produ=
ce connectivity patterns
	=95 Spatial CPPN: a CPPN interpreted to produce s=
patial patterns
	=95 NEAT: NeuroEvolution for Augmenting Topologies
	=95 Hy=
perNEAT: NEAT for evolving connective CPPNs


Cheers,

Evert

On 23 Jan 201=
0, at 07:08, Ken wrote:

>
>
> I wanted to follow up a little on the HyperN=
EAT tutorial issue. We  
> have started to update the HyperNEAT Users Page =
FAQ section with  
> tutorial-like questions, so it is slowly starting to f=
ulfill some of  
> the hopes of such a reference. The page is:
>
> http://e=
plex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html
>
> On the left-hand side, cli=
ck on "HyperNEAT Methodology FAQ."
>
> Hopefully some of the answers there =
address common questions for  
> beginners (or even not beginners) with Hyp=
erNEAT. We do plan to  
> expand the list over time.
>
> ken
>
> --- In nea=
t@yahoogroups.com, "Ken" <kstanley@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> >
> > We're still =
thinking about whether to provide a wiki or try to  
> provide more somethi=
ng more static. The wiki presents several  
> possible challenges. For exam=
ple, it could turn out sparse or die  
> out if not enough people add to it=
. On the other hand, it could fill  
> up with inaccurate information or ev=
en spam, which would require  
> policing. At the moment we are considering=
 more static tutorial-like  
> introductions but a wiki is a possibility. I=
f people have thoughts  
> on the Wiki idea I am happy to hear them.
> >
> =
> ken
> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> > =
>
> > > Hello all-
> > >
> > > I like the idea of a tutorial, especially wi=
th respect to the  
> many HyperNEAT
> > > (NEAT) parameters. For example, =
I just had a question internally  
> about what
> > > the SpeciesSizeTarget=
 would be, and had to search around for a  
> while to find
> > > the threa=
d on the NEAT list where I had previously asked about  
> this
> > > parame=
ter (and Ken provided a helpful answer, pasted below).
> > >
> > > It would=
 be great to capture this knowledge in a wiki, instead  
> of just in
> > >=
 this forum, and let people add their own thoughts. That way, a  
> researc=
her
> > > could read a paragraph or three about the parameter they are  
> =
wondering
> > > about, which can help them understand it and possibly optim=
ize  
> it for their
> > > problem. It would probably also highlight which =
parameters we  
> have not yet
> > > had discussions about, so people can f=
ill in their own rules of  
> thumb for
> > > that parameter.
> > >
> > > H=
ere was Ken's reply about SpeciesSizeTarget:
> > > >>> I haven't seen any e=
xplicit studies on population size in NEAT
> > > >>> specifically, but ther=
e have been such studies for genetic  
> algorithms
> > > >>> in general. I=
 think Kenneth De Jong's textbook, "Evolutionary
> > > >>> Computation: A U=
nified Perspective" examines it.
> > > >>>
> > > >>> However, of course as =
people have pointed out in NEAT it's  
> not just a
> > > >>> question of a=
 healthy population but of healthy species,  
> since each
> > > >>> specie=
s is like its own little population. In other words, the
> > > >>> species =
need enough internal diversity to drive their own
> > > >>> explorations. M=
y own rule of thumb has been a minimum of 15  
> members
> > > >>> per spec=
ies (on average) to keep them healthy. I'm sure 30  
> is even
> > > >>> sa=
fer.
> > > >>>
> > > >>> Another thing to note is that the population size =
you need  
> can vary
> > > >>> wildly by problem and it can be surprising.=
 For pole  
> balancing, it
> > > >>> turns out that you can solve it faste=
st with a minuscule  
> population of
> > > >>> size under 20 total (that's=
 for the whole population!). That  
> is
> > > >>> because smaller populati=
ons are greedier (they concentrate  
> resources
> > > >>> on a small part =
of the search space) and apparently pole  
> balancing
> > > >>> benefits g=
reatly from greedy search. However, that is a  
> specific
> > > >>> proper=
ty of pole balancing and I would not expect it to  
> carry over to
> > > >=
>> more significant domains. Surely in some domains having a  
> population=

> > > >>> over 1000 would lead to the most interesting results, if  
> onl=
y you can
> > > >>> afford the luxury of the added computational cost of a =
large  
> population.
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > Cheers,
> > > Jeff Clun=
e
> > >
> > > Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> > > jclune=
@
> > > www.msu.edu/~jclune
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > > From: Ken <ksta=
nley@>
> > > > Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> > =
> > Date: Sat, 28 Nov 2009 22:00:25 -0000
> > > > To: "neat@yahoogroups.com=
" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> > > > Subject: [neat] Re: HyperNEAT Tutorial?
> =
> > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Anthony,
> > > >
> > > > We are hoping to mak=
e the HyperNEAT Users Page at
> > > > http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage=
/HyperNEAT.html into a  
> place where people
> > > > can have questions li=
ke yours answered. The "Introduction /  
> What is
> > > > HyperNEAT?" sect=
ion on that page is intended to provide some  
> general answers
> > > > to=
 beginners without having to read a research paper. Did that  
> section he=
lp
> > > > you at all? I'd like to make the page as useful as possible  
> =
and we will
> > > > continue to improve it.
> > > >
> > > > To answer your =
question, HyperNEAT is a significant step  
> beyond NEAT so it
> > > > inv=
olves a lot of new ideas that aren't part of the original  
> NEAT. Some of=

> > > > those concepts can theoretically be applied on top of non-NEAT  
>=
 methods. For
> > > > example, in the following paper, NEAT is substituted =
with GP  
> to create a
> > > > "HyperGP," in which GP evolves the CPPN:
> =
> > >
> > > > Buk Z., Koutn=EDk J., =8Anorek M., NEAT in HyperNEAT Substitu=
ted  
> with Genetic
> > > > Programming, In: ICANNGA 2009.
> > > > http://=
cig.felk.cvut.cz/research/publications/hypergp.pdf
> > > >
> > > > That sai=
d, HyperNEAT addresses a limitation of NEAT, which is  
> a limitation of
>=
 > > > all direct encodings: In NEAT, there is one gene for every  
> conne=
ction in the
> > > > network. Even with complexification, that kind of  
> =
representation cannot hope
> > > > to scale to networks with millions or mo=
re connections,  
> because such networks
> > > > would have millions or mo=
re genes, which is an astronomical  
> search space.
> > > >
> > > > Howeve=
r, there are in fact 100 trillion connections in the  
> human brain, which=

> > > > means that in principle it is possible to evolve such  
> structur=
es. Yet there
> > > > are only about 30,000 genes in the human genome, whic=
h  
> suggests that any
> > > > evolutionary approach to evolving large-sca=
le neural networks  
> must encode the
> > > > connection weights in a comp=
ressed description, which is  
> called an indirect
> > > > encoding.
> > >=
 >
> > > > In HyperNEAT, the indirect encoding is the CPPN, which encodes  =

> the
> > > > connectivity of a network as a pattern across its geometry. =
 
> HyperNEAT
> > > > combines the idea of indirect encoding with a strong =
notion of  
> geometry and
> > > > builds on our understanding of encoding =
patterns to produce an  
> algorithm that
> > > > encodes large-scale topog=
raphies (i.e. connection weights  
> across a geometry).
> > > > Thus it ex=
tends NEAT by giving it the power of indirect  
> encoding, thereby
> > > >=
 greatly expanding the scope of networks it can evolve.
> > > >
> > > > Of =
course NEAT is still there under the hood. NEAT is evolving  
> the CPPNs,
=
> > > > which in turn encode neural networks (called substrates in  
> Hype=
rNEAT). The
> > > > CPPNs themselves are still complexifying. However, that=
  
> complexification is
> > > > no longer literally adding one connection =
at a time to a  
> neural network.
> > > > Rather it is adding *information=
* to the encoding, so that it  
> can encode more
> > > > complex *holistic=
* connectivity patterns. In other words,  
> HyperNEAT means
> > > > that e=
volution is no longer limited by the dimensionality of  
> the inputs and
>=
 > > > outputs but rather can search for the correct implicit problem  
> c=
omplexity,
> > > > whatever that may be, inside the CPPN. The substrate (wh=
ich  
> the CPPN encodes)
> > > > will then have as many connections as it =
needs, in principle  
> up to millions or
> > > > even trillions (with enou=
gh CPU power).
> > > >
> > > > It is true that geometry may be vague or dif=
ficult to decide  
> in some problems.
> > > > Those may be more difficult =
for users to approach with  
> HyperNEAT. Yet I think
> > > > most if not a=
ll problems can ultimately be posed within some  
> geometry, even if
> > >=
 > it is abstract or conceptual. As Jeff Clune has shown
> > > > (https://w=
ww.msu.edu/~jclune/webfiles/publications/Clune-HyperNEATSensitivityT
> > > =
> oGeometry.pdf), geometry does not need to be perfect, or  
> necessarily =
even
> > > > close to perfect, for HyperNEAT to still find some  
> regular=
ities to exploit, so
> > > > while it may be an imperfect art, geometry is =
still ultimately  
> a useful tool
> > > > for conveying exploitable inform=
ation about a domain.
> > > >
> > > > I hope that provides some insight,
> =
> > >
> > > > ken
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ant=
hony Ison" <anthony.ison@>  
> wrote:
> > > >>
> > > >> I'd like to add my =
vote to some kind of non-research style  
> tutorial -
> > > >> especially =
towards the HyperNEAT methodology.
> > > >>
> > > >>
> > > >>
> > > >> Is t=
here somewhere I can get an overview of how the CPPN is  
> actually
> > > =
>> used and what it does? I've looked through a number of papers  
> on the=

> > > >> main HyperNEAT site, but I feel like I'm missing something. I  
>=
 have read
> > > >> that HyperNEAT is the future of NEAT - does this apply =
to  
> problems where
> > > >> there is no useful input geometry? I underst=
and how NEAT  
> grows a
> > > >> network by adding nodes and connections a=
nd overall I love  
> the concept.
> > > >> It makes sense that a learning =
network can adjust itself to  
> improve its
> > > >> performance. What I d=
on't really understand is how a CPPN is  
> involved
> > > >> in this proce=
ss.
> > > >>
> > > >>
> > > >>
> > > >> Is anyone able to give a short over=
view on what HyperNEAT  
> offers over
> > > >> NEAT?
> > > >>
> > > >>
> >=
 > >>
> > > >> Cheers,
> > > >>
> > > >> Anthony
> > > >>
> > > >>
> > > >>=

> > > >>
> > > >>
> > > >> From: dkuppitz [mailto:daniel_kuppitz@]
> > > >=
> Sent: Monday, 23 November 2009 9:08 AM
> > > >> To: neat@yahoogroups.com
=
> > > >> Subject: [neat] Re: HyperNEAT Tutorial?
> > > >>
> > > >>
> > > >>=

> > > >>
> > > >>
> > > >> Hello Ken,
> > > >>
> > > >> here's just anothe=
r vote for a tutorial, with the difference  
> that I
> > > >> would prefer=
 it for HyperSharpNEAT.
> > > >>
> > > >> It would be great to see somethin=
g like a HOL (Hands on Labs)  
> where a
> > > >> new experiment is created=
 from the scratch. Parameters should  
> be
> > > >> explained in detail, f=
or example: Which impact has the  
> parameter
> > > >> Treshold, which imp=
act has WeightRange, etc.? How are the  
> values for
> > > >> each paramet=
er determined, what is taken into account when  
> you set the
> > > >> val=
ues? There are so many unanswered questions for those who  
> are new to
> =
> > >> HyperNEAT and I think most people (including me) have a  
> really g=
reat
> > > >> interest in this topic, but not the time to read (and  
> und=
erstand) all
> > > >> the technical papers. So any tutorial should target b=
eginners  
> and
> > > >> explain things that have become self-evident for =
intermediates.
> > > >>
> > > >> I think one such "official" tutorial that =
explains every step  
> in detail
> > > >> should be enough, more will sure=
ly follow from the growing  
> community.
> > > >>
> > > >> Cheers,
> > > >=
> Daniel
> > > >>
> > > >> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <mailto:neat%40yahoo=
groups.com> ,  
> "Ken"
> > > >> <kstanley@> wrote:
> > > >>>
> > > >>>
> >=
 > >>>
> > > >>> Andrei, which version of HyperNEAT are you interested in a=
nd  
> what
> > > >> references have you looked at so far? We can potential=
ly  
> improve the
> > > >> documentation based on your comments (and a tut=
orial is a  
> good idea),
> > > >> but first I want to understand which "c=
omment-less examples"  
> you are
> > > >> referring to.
> > > >>>
> > > >>=
> Note that several experiments with complete source code are  
> available=

> > > >> in two existing HyperNEAT releases of which I am aware. These  
>=
 and a
> > > >> variety of publications from several groups are linked from=
 the
> > > >> HyperNEAT Users Page, which also provides a brief introductio=
n:
> > > >>>
> > > >>> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html=

> > > >>>
> > > >>> I understand you may have already been through this si=
te and  
> its
> > > >> associated software and papers, but I wanted to poi=
nt it out  
> in case you
> > > >> had not been aware of it.
> > > >>>
> > =
> >>> We want to make the algorithm as accessible as possible so  
> your
>=
 > > >> comments are appreciated.
> > > >>>
> > > >>> ken
> > > >>>
> > > >=
>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <mailto:neat 
> %40yahoogroups.com> , "Andre=
i"
> > > >> <andrei.rusu@> wrote:
> > > >>>>
> > > >>>> Can anyone please r=
ecommend some HyperNEAT documentation, a
> > > >> tutorial, diagram, some c=
lue, or anything that does not mean  
> reverse
> > > >> engineering the co=
mment-less examples ?
> > > >>>>
> > > >>>> Thanks! Andrei.
> > > >>>>
> > =
> >>>
> > > >>
> > > >
> > > >
> > >

n's reply about SpeciesSizeTarget:<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> =
> >>> I haven't seen any explicit studies on population size in=
 NEAT<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > >>> specificall=
y, but there have been such studies for genetic algorithms<br style=3D"line=
-height: 1.22em; ">> > >>> in general. I think Kenneth De Jo=
ng's textbook, "Evolutionary<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > &=
gt;>> Computation: A Unified Perspective" examines it.<br style=3D"li=
ne-height: 1.22em; ">> > >>><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em=
; ">> > >>> However, of course as people have pointed out in=
 NEAT it's not just a<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > >>=
> question of a healthy population but of healthy species, since each<br=
 style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > >>> species is like its=
 own little population. In other words, the<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em=
; ">> > >>> species need enough internal diversity to drive =
their own<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > >>> explora=
tions. My own rule of thumb has been a minimum of 15 members<br style=3D"li=
ne-height: 1.22em; ">> > >>> per species (on average) to kee=
p them healthy. I'm sure 30 is even<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">>=
 > >>> safer.<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > >=
>><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > >>> Another =
thing to note is that the population size you need can vary<br style=3D"lin=
e-height: 1.22em; ">> > >>> wildly by problem and it can be =
surprising. For pole balancing, it<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> =
> >>> turns out that you can solve it fastest with a minuscule =
population of<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > >>> siz=
e under 20 total (that's for the whole population!)<wbr style=3D"line-heigh=
t: 1.22em; ">. That is<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > >&gt=
;> because smaller populations are greedier (they concentrate resources<=
br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > >>> on a small part o=
f the search space) and apparently pole balancing<br style=3D"line-height: =
1.22em; ">> > >>> benefits greatly from greedy search. Howev=
er, that is a specific<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > >&gt=
;> property of pole balancing and I would not expect it to carry over to=
<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > >>> more significant=
 domains. Surely in some domains having a population<br style=3D"line-heigh=
t: 1.22em; ">> > >>> over 1000 would lead to the most intere=
sting results, if only you can<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> >=
 >>> afford the luxury of the added computational cost of a large =
population.<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> ><span class=3D"Appl=

;</span><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > To answer your q=
uestion, HyperNEAT is a significant step beyond NEAT so it<br style=3D"line=
-height: 1.22em; ">> > > involves a lot of new ideas that aren't p=
art of the original NEAT. Some of<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> &=
gt; > those concepts can theoretically be applied on top of non-NEAT met=
hods. For<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > example, in the=
 following paper, NEAT is substituted with GP to create a<br style=3D"line-=
height: 1.22em; ">> > > "HyperGP," in which GP evolves the CPPN:<b=
r style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > ><span class=3D"Apple-conver=
ted-space"> </span><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > =
Buk Z., Koutn=EDk J., =8Anorek M., NEAT in HyperNEAT Substituted with Genet=
ic<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > Programming, In: ICANN=
GA 2009.<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > ><span class=3D"Ap=
ple-converted-space"> </span><a href=3D"http://cig.felk.cvut.cz/resear=
ch/publications/hypergp.pdf" style=3D"color: rgb(30, 102, 174); line-height=
: 1.22em; font-family: Verdana; ">http://cig.felk.<wbr style=3D"line-height=
: 1.22em; ">cvut.cz/research<wbr style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">/publicati=
ons/<wbr style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">hypergp.pdf</a><br style=3D"line-h=
eight: 1.22em; ">> > ><span class=3D"Apple-converted-space"> =
</span><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > That said, HyperN=
EAT addresses a limitation of NEAT, which is a limitation of<br style=3D"li=
ne-height: 1.22em; ">> > > all direct encodings: In NEAT, there is=
 one gene for every connection in the<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">&g=
t; > > network. Even with complexification, that kind of representati=
on cannot hope<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > to scale t=
o networks with millions or more connections, because such networks<br styl=
e=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > would have millions or more gene=
s, which is an astronomical search space.<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; =
">> > ><span class=3D"Apple-converted-space"> </span><br styl=
e=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > However, there are in fact 100 t=
rillion connections in the human brain, which<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22=
em; ">> > > means that in principle it is possible to evolve such =
structures. Yet there<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > are=
 only about 30,000 genes in the human genome, which suggests that any<br st=
yle=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > evolutionary approach to evolv=
ing large-scale neural networks must encode the<br style=3D"line-height: 1.=
22em; ">> > > connection weights in a compressed description, whic=
h is called an indirect<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > e=
ncoding.<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > ><span class=3D"Ap=
ple-converted-space"> </span><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> =
> > In HyperNEAT, the indirect encoding is the CPPN, which encodes th=
e<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > connectivity of a netwo=
rk as a pattern across its geometry. HyperNEAT<br style=3D"line-height: 1.2=
2em; ">> > > combines the idea of indirect encoding with a strong =
notion of geometry and<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > bu=
ilds on our understanding of encoding patterns to produce an algorithm that=
<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > encodes large-scale topo=
graphies (i.e. connection weights across a geometry).<br style=3D"line-heig=
ht: 1.22em; ">> > > Thus it extends NEAT by giving it the power of=
 indirect encoding, thereby<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > &g=
t; greatly expanding the scope of networks it can evolve.<br style=3D"line-=
height: 1.22em; ">> > ><span class=3D"Apple-converted-space">&nbsp=
;</span><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > Of course NEAT i=
s still there under the hood. NEAT is evolving the CPPNs,<br style=3D"line-=
height: 1.22em; ">> > > which in turn encode neural networks (call=
ed substrates in HyperNEAT). The<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> &g=
t; > CPPNs themselves are still complexifying. However, that complexific=
ation is<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > no longer litera=
lly adding one connection at a time to a neural network.<br style=3D"line-h=
eight: 1.22em; ">> > > Rather it is adding *information* to the en=
coding, so that it can encode more<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> =
> > complex *holistic* connectivity patterns. In other words, HyperNE=
AT means<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > that evolution i=
s no longer limited by the dimensionality of the inputs and<br style=3D"lin=
e-height: 1.22em; ">> > > outputs but rather can search for the co=
rrect implicit problem complexity,<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> =
> > whatever that may be, inside the CPPN. The substrate (which the C=
PPN encodes)<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > will then ha=
ve as many connections as it needs, in principle up to millions or<br style=
=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > even trillions (with enough CPU p=
ower).<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > ><span class=3D"Appl=
e-converted-space"> </span><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> &g=
t; > It is true that geometry may be vague or difficult to decide in som=
e problems.<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > Those may be =
more difficult for users to approach with HyperNEAT. Yet I think<br style=
=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > most if not all problems can ulti=
mately be posed within some geometry, even if<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22=
em; ">> > > it is abstract or conceptual. As Jeff Clune has shown<=
br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">> > > (<a href=3D"https://www.m=
su.edu/~jclune/webfiles/publications/Clune-HyperNEATSensitivityT" style=3D"=
color: rgb(30, 102, 174); line-height: 1.22em; font-family: Verdana; ">http=
s://www.<wbr style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">msu.edu/~<wbr style=3D"line-he=
ight: 1.22em; ">jclune/webfiles/<wbr style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">public=
ations/<wbr style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">Clune-HyperNEATS<wbr style=3D"l=
ine-height: 1.22em; ">ensitivityT</a><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">&g=
t; > > oGeometry.pdf)<wbr style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ">, geometry =
does not need to be perfect, or necessarily even<br style=3D"line-height: 1=
.22em; ">> > > close to perfect, for HyperNEAT to still find some =
